entry.title: What is new in S/4HANA Manufacturing for Production Engineering & Operations (PEO) in 2025 FPS0
entry.content:
What is new in S/4HANA Manufacturing for Production Engineering & Operations (PEO) in 2025 FPS0

The 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for production engineering and operations (PEO) offers significant enhancements that streamline manufacturing processes, improve operational flexibility, and enhance user experience across the production lifecycle. This blog post explores the key innovations in the areas of product rework capabilities, production engineering efficiency, flexible production operations, and extensibility improvements.

 

Product Rework

PEO now enables comprehensive rework capabilities for products at any time after completion of their production order, including externally procured products. This functionality allows replacement of defective or degraded components identified for completed orders, as well as repairs or maintenance on products that have been in storage or returned from the field. The system provides the same level of traceability for product rework orders as for standard shop floor orders, ensuring complete visibility throughout the process.

 

For more information, see Performing Product Rework | SAP Help Portal.

Production Engineering Efficiency

Automatic Plan-as-Designed with Phantom Flattening

The shop floor BOM in PEO does not expect phantom assemblies. But many customers define mBOMs in PLM systems with phantom assemblies. Using this new capability in PEO, the upstream PLM system can now send mBOMs with phantom assemblies to PEO, which are then automatically processed to create shop floor BOM by doing automated plan-as-design with phantom flattening. Shop floor BOM is created as a mirror of the incoming mBOM but if phantom assemblies are found, they are automatically flattened. The phantom hierarchy information is available for production engineer while working with shop floor routing management and also for production worker while using Perform Work Apps.

Business benefits include:

  • Valuable information on phantom hierarchies is not lost
  • Huge time savings when combined with workflow automation

For more information, see Automatic Plan-As-Designed | SAP Help Portal.

Work Instructions: Usability Improvements

Usability has been improved in both interactive and non-interactive work instructions. When adding references to inspection characteristics and PRTs, you can now add multiple references in one step. Multiple selection is also now supported when you add document links.

 

 

In addition, logical components can now be cross-referenced in work instructions.

For more information, see How to Maintain Work Instructions for Operation Activities | SAP Help Portal.

Manage Production Model: Support for Unitized Products

The Manage Production Models - Materials app now enables you to create and manage production models for unitized products. You can define production models at unit level to support different customer requirements, thereby optimizing your production planning.

A Parameter Effectivity section has been added to the details page for components, operations, and operation activities.

 

You can also release a production model version for a subset of the MBOM effectivity range.

 

For more information, see Manage Production Model ‚Äì Materials | SAP Help Portal.

 

Manage Production Model: Create Sales-Order-Specific BOM and Routing for Non-Configurable Products

 


The Manage Production Models - Engineer-to-Order app now supports the creation of ETO production models for non-configurable materials such as material type HALB (Semifinished Product) or FERT (Finished Product). A simple guided procedure takes users through the steps to create an ETO production model using a sales order for a non-configurable material and engineer it further by adding components and production steps. This enables meeting special customer requirements even when the material in the sales order is not configurable.

For more information, see Manage Production Model ‚Äì Engineer-to-Order | SAP Help Portal.

 

Assign Documents to Operations in Routings

You can now assign documents at operation level in shop floor routings. Documents applicable to all operation activities of a specific operation now only need to be assigned once, saving time and effort while eliminating the risk of different and contradictory information being displayed for each operation activity.

 

For more information, see How to Assign Documents to Operations | SAP Help Portal.

Usability Improvements for Shop Floor Routing Template Handling

To allow for easier organization of templates in the folder view, you can now cut a template and paste it at a different position in the structure.

 

When you display the template library, the system automatically filters the list of templates by the production plant of the template that you're editing. This improves performance and usability by reducing the number of templates initially displayed.

 

 

Flexible Production Operations

Perform OA: Usability Improvement for Displaying Documents

In the Perform Operation Activity app, document service control has been replaced by a responsive table to enable file previews within the app. You can now view and download documents and attachments more easily directly within the app.

 

For more information, see Perform Operation Activity | SAP Help Portal.

Parallel Operations Using Parallel Sequences

PEO shop floor routing now supports the creation of sequences for scheduling order operations to run in parallel, like classic routings. A parallel sequence branches from and returns to operations in a reference sequence, with operations in a parallel sequence performed in parallel to operations in the reference sequence. This functionality provides greater process and scheduling flexibility to reduce production time, better utilize resources, and support different manufacturing scenarios.

 

For more information, see How to Create Parallel Sequences | SAP Help Portal.

Alternative Components: Simple Discontinuation

Sometimes prescribed components may be in shortage in shop floor. Using the definition of alternative components, the production engineer can specify alternative components that can be used in such cases. In addition to defining alternative components in BOM, PEO now supports the use of global alternatives defined using simple discontinuation in the material master record.

 

 

Components in the production order can be exchanged for follow-up materials that have been defined using simple discontinuation.

 

This provides more flexibility to replace components in a production order due to defects, stock shortages, or changes in safety requirements without having to update the BOM.

PEO tracks the use of global alternatives in the end-to-end process.

For more information, see Using Global Alternatives | SAP Help Portal.

Extended Quality Check (EQC) Groups

PEO provides the capability of extended quality check (EQC) to enable modelling of regulatory and compliance requirements like first article inspection (FAI), first piece inspection (FPI) or other kind of compliances during production. With EQC production engineer can define conditional operations, operation activities or data collection which generally not applicable for normal production but can be exposed in production orders which requires such extended checks.

PEO has introduced EQC groups to support partial extended quality checks. You define EQC groups in Customizing. Through the assignment of EQC groups to operation activities and inspection characteristics in the shop floor routing, it‚Äôs now possible to implement partial extended quality checks. During creation of a shop floor order, EQC groups can be selected, resulting in only those operation activities and inspection characteristics assigned to the selected EQC groups being included in the shop floor order, along with non-EQC-relevant operation activities.

In the example below the production engineer has defined some additional activities tagged with relevant EQC Groups. While creating the order, it can be identified as an order which requires for example in this case ‚ÄòFull FAI‚Äô or ‚ÄòPartial FAI‚Äô or ‚ÄòFirst Piece‚Äô and depending upon these relevant activities are exposed in the order. Multiple EQC groups can also be assigned to an order.

 

Benefits include:

  • Capability to perform delta or selected quality checks after a full EQC
  • Flexibility to perform partial quality checks across orders if production-related issues prevent a full EQC in a single order

For more information, see Extended Quality Checks | SAP Help Portal.

Qualifications for Buyoff Steps

HR qualifications can now be assigned to each buyoff step in an operation activity.

 


This functionality allows control over who can approve buyoff steps at production completion, ensuring higher quality assurance and improving compliance and audit readiness.

For more information, see How to Assign Buyoffs to Operation Activities | SAP Help Portal.

Retain Serial Number Group Across Operation Activities (Pull Scenario)

 
 

 


Production operators can now copy a serial number group that was completed at the previous operation activity to a new group at the selected operation activity when starting an operation activity in the My Work Queue app (pull scenario).

 

 

This provides more flexibility in copying serial number groups, especially when the production operator performing an operation activity is not the same operator who completed the previous operation activity.

For more information, see How to Copy Serial Number Groups from Previous Operation Activity | SAP Help Portal.

Data Collection: Capture Test Equipment Used

When collecting data in the Perform Operation Activity app, you can now select the test equipment used for a specific inspection characteristic.

 

Benefits of this feature are:

  • Improved traceability and compliance
  • Allows the operator to record unplanned test equipment that was used for the IC

For more information, see How to Record Inspection Characteristics | SAP Help Portal.

Exposing Inspection Method to Production Worker

Inspection methods can now be referenced in shop floor routings. This means that production engineers can:

  • Reference an inspection method when adding an IC.
  • Include the inspection method when referencing ICs in interactive and non-interactive work instructions.

The production operator can navigate to the inspection method from the Perform Operation Activity app, view the details, and then navigate back to the operation activity.

 

For more information, see How to Assign Inspection Method to Inspection Characteristics | SAP Help Portal.

Other New Capabilities

Modernization of Tables in Perform OA App Using Smart Tables

SAP Fiori smart tables are now used to display component data, PRTs, and data collection for operation activities that have simple work instructions or no work instructions. This modernization provides app extensibility for key users and delivers better look and feel and behavior of the UI.

 

Improved Extensibility in Authoring of Interactive Work Instructions

New Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) have been introduced, which you can use to fill custom fields for components, inspection characteristics, and PRTs that are referenced in both interactive and non-interactive work instructions

 

The custom field values are then displayed in the work instructions in the Perform Operation Activity app.

Want to Find Out More?

You can find more information on all new features provided in SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for production engineering and operations (PEO) Release 2025 FPS0 here:

  • What's New | SAP Help Portal  ‚Äì just go to Manufacturing for Production Engineering and Operations

entry.title: PY-ID: Is the Retroactive Payroll Run the Right Answer in All HR Scenarios? (TER Tax method)
entry.content:
From the teaser, two key terms are highlighted: Employment Status and TER Tax Method.

Employment Status in the Payroll System There are four employment status values used for reporting and time constrain validation:

  • 3 Active
  • 1 Inactive - Typically used for sabbatical or unpaid leave.
  • 2 Retiree - Retired employees who may receive additional payments
  • 0 Withdrawn - No longer employed by the company.

TER Tax calculation and Tariff for PPh21

  • The Monthly TER tax uses three tax rate tables A, B and C.
    • Refer to SAP Note 3409916 
    • Legal reference Regulation 58/2023 and PMK 168/2023
  • The Final tax uses Tariff 17 which is a progressive tax rate ranging from 5% to 35%.
    • Refer to SAP Note 3108070 
    • Legal reference Harmony of Tax regulation HARMONI SASI PERATURAN PERPAJAI, published in Nov 2021
  • Post payment tax after termination month.

Which TER tax calculation applies to which employment status? Let's explore this through different HR Business Scenario.

  1. Employee works the full tax year.
    • Employment Status: Active.
    • Last payroll period: December.
  2. Employee terminates in the mid of tax year.
    • Employment Status Active -> Withdrawn.
    • Termination date on 1st July.
    • Last payroll period: June
  3. Employee take unpaid leave (April - June).
    • Employment Status is Active -> Inactive -> Active.
    • Last payroll period: December

These scenarios illustrate that the TER Tax Rate applies only to Active employees, while the Final Tax (Tariff 17) applies to both Active and other employment statuses.

The TER and Final Tax methods differ in both calculation logic and applicable tax rates. It is straightforward when these methods are applied separately, as they are not meant to be combined.

Payment Scenarios in HR Business

Both TER and Final tax methods are payment-date based. This means the payment date determines the payroll period in which the income is taxed.

Example:

  • Example 1: If a company pays an additional allowance in July, but the payment letter is effective from June, the allowance is included in July's gross income for tax purposes. June's tax is not recalculated.

In this case, Payroll Administrator maintain pay date in June and a retroactive payroll is triggered and supported.

  • Refer to SAP Note 3472667 
  •  The difference from June is added to July's payroll as part of the total gross income. 
  • Employment Status on both June and July : Active
  • Example 2: Retroactive Payment with Inactive Status
  • If employee was on unpaid leave from April to June, and the company pays an additional allowance in July (Employment Status: Active), but the payment letter is effective from June (Employment Status: Inactive), the allowance is included in July's gross income for tax purposes. June's tax is not recalculated.

In this case, Payroll Administrator should not maintain pay date in June because employee was Inactive and July's tax is submitted using the Final tax (Tariff 17).

  • Refer to SAP Note 3472667 
  • Note: Once the last period payroll is finished(using the TER YEA method), it is not supported to do gross retro. Maintain the difference into current period directly instead.
  •  The difference from June is added to July's payroll as part of the total gross income by Payroll Administrator manually includes the difference in July's payroll. 
  • Employment Status in June - Inactive;  July - Active

In response to the question, the retroactive payroll run is not always the appropriate solution in all HR scenarios under TER Tax Method. We do not recommend retroactive run in cases involving difference tax calculation methods, such as unpaid leave or backdated termination.

  • Under the Indonesia TER Tax method, tax is calculated based on the payment date, meaning only the current month's income is considered.
  • The Final Tax calculation includes tax exemptions that are not present in the monthly TER method. As a result, recalculating tax using a different method may lead to inaccurate results.
  • Additionally, correcting previously submitted tax data to the government can be complex and time-consuming.

entry.title: SAP Business Network, Upgraded: The Six Big Things You Get on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Tariffs, geopolitics, and a rising thicket of e-invoicing and traceability mandates are the new normal. The question is not if you will adapt, but how you can do it without breaking what already works. The answer is SAP Business Network‚Äôs upgrade to SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

This is more than a technical refresh. It is a platform shift that unlocks scale, resilience, and intelligence across your extended ecosystem. From day one, you gain a modern cloud foundation, a unified suite experience, embedded AI, and regional data federation. The platform is purpose-built for compliance and growth.

Why now

Volatile demand, cross-border friction, and regulatory churn require infrastructure that scales instantly and integrates cleanly while keeping data where it must legally reside. That is why SAP is moving the world‚Äôs largest B2B network to BTP, so you can orchestrate complex, multi-tier supply chains with cloud-scale performance and suite-level trust. With the rapid adoption of AI, data consistency matters even more. AI is only as valuable as the data you feed it. Moving SAP Business Network to BTP aligns network data to the suite-wide domain model used across SAP applications. You get a single foundation that makes analytics reliable, AI outputs trustworthy, and cross-process orchestration possible through BTP workflow services.

AI and analytics are foundational capabilities of BTP. As SAP advances these services across the suite, SAP Business Network gains the same improvements automatically. New models, copilots, and analytic features arrive through the platform, so the network improves in step with the rest of SAP without separate rework.

Six capabilities that set the new standard

  1. Cloud-scale performance: Run critical flows on a cloud-native architecture designed for speed, elasticity, and reliability so spikes never become slowdowns. Customers already see faster processing and higher uptime as transaction loads grow.
  2. Data sovereignty and federation: Operate globally while keeping data local. Data center federation ensures information stays in-region to meet residency rules, yet authorized users can collaborate and search across regions through a central Trading Partner Directory with strong identity and access controls. Buyers in the EU, for example, can work seamlessly with suppliers in the US without centralizing the data.
  3. Unified suite experience: Business Network now shares core services with the SAP suite, including identity, workflow, and analytics. Because data follows a consistent domain model across SAP, records look and behave the same from ERP to network. You get a clean, consistent experience, a single workflow inbox, aligned process semantics, and tangible UX improvements in purchase orders, invoices, notifications, and transaction rules. Since AI and analytics are delivered through BTP services, improvements ship once at the platform level and appear in Business Network at the same time as the rest of the suite.
  4. Extensibility without chaos: Build and adapt faster without disrupting your core. On BTP you have full-stack options: open APIs and pro-code services, plus SAP Build for low-code and no-code app development, process automation, and secure workspaces. Because the suite uses a common domain model, extensions are easier to design, reuse, and govern, and they connect cleanly from ERP to the network. Accelerate delivery with prebuilt content, connectors, and SAP and partner apps available on BTP. Compose cross-process automations with BTP workflow services to coordinate tasks across processes. Tap into a large network of SAP-certified partners and practitioners to extend further.
  5. Embedded intelligence and a path to orchestration: AI is not a bolt-on. With SAP Business AI and Joule-powered assistance, you get smarter decisions and predictive insights where work happens today. Because data is aligned across the suite and orchestrated by BTP workflows, AI can move from recommending actions to initiating them across processes and trading partners with the right controls in place. As SAP advances models, copilots, and analytics on BTP, those upgrades flow to Business Network without separate projects.
  6. Non-disruptive upgrade and continuity: This is an upgrade, not a re-implementation. Behind the scenes, data migration is automated and open documents are preserved. Buyer and supplier cutovers are decoupled to protect in-flight transactions, so day-to-day operations continue without disruption. 

SAP Business Network, Upgraded: The Six Big Things You Get on SAP BTP

Tariffs, geopolitics, and a rising thicket of e-invoicing and traceability mandates are the new normal. The question is not if you will adapt, but how you can do it without breaking what already works. The answer is SAP Business Network‚Äôs upgrade to SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). This is more than a technical refresh. It is a platform shift that unlocks scale, resilience, and intelligence across your extended ecosystem.

From day one, you gain a modern cloud foundation, a unified suite experience, embedded AI, and regional data federation. The platform is purpose-built for compliance and growth.

What is new that you can feel

  • A cleaner, faster UI for purchase orders, invoices, notifications, and rules. Navigation is clearer, search is stronger, and dependencies and statuses are visible in one place.
  • Smarter partner connectivity with a central directory and synchronized search across profiles, catalogs, and documents. Finding, inviting, and collaborating with partners across tiers is simpler.
  • Onboarding automation that segments supplier waves, sends branded invitations, monitors progress, and accelerates relationship building.
  • Cross-process workflow orchestration that ties steps together across applications, so exceptions trigger the right actions in the right systems with less manual effort.

What this means for your ecosystem

  • Supply chain orchestration with confidence: Spot issues earlier, resolve exceptions faster, and coordinate responses across multiple tiers even as mandates shift and markets move.
  • Connectivity that meets you where you are: Native SAP connectivity and simplified third-party integration reduce friction across ERP, line-of-business apps, and the network. You can modernize at your own pace.
  • Automation with guardrails: Use AI and workflow services to scale decision-making while adhering to corporate controls and regional compliance requirements.

Bottom line

SAP Business Network on SAP BTP gives you the scale, sovereignty, extensibility, and intelligence to collaborate across processes and partners with the consistency enterprises expect. In a world where resilience is a competitive advantage, this upgrade helps you see more, decide faster, and act together without disruption.

entry.title: SAP Business Planning and Consolidation (SAP BPC) Strategy Update
entry.content:
As most of you should be well informed, SAP launched early this year SAP Business Data Cloud(BDC) - a fully managed SaaS solution.  SAP Business Warehouse(BW) modernization is a critical path to SAP Business Data Cloud, it provides the most economical route to the cloud. With Business Data Cloud, customers maximize their existing BW data as data products and take advantage of the latest data and AI capabilities.

Along with moving your SAP BW 7.50 or SAP BW/4HANA to a private cloud environment(PCE) in Business Data Cloud, you can also move your SAP BPC 10.1 NW  or SAP BPC 2021 at the same time.

 

Now let‚Äôs have a look on updated maintenance strategy for different SAP BPC Products.

SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 2021, version for SAP BW/4HANA 2021


SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 2021 supports both SAP BW/4HANA 2021 and 2023 with end of maintenance by 31.12.2030(as of now).

As we explained in our previous blog, this BPC product which supports the SAP BW/4HANA product line will be aligned with the SAP S/4HANA maintenance extension and will be maintained until at least 2040. This means there will always be a corresponding SAP BPC/4HANA product version which supports the latest SAP BW/4HANA release. The corresponding release name will be communicated in a timely manner. 

SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 10.1, version for SAP NetWeaver

SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 10.1 NW has mainstream maintenance until 31.12.2027 along with an extended maintenance until 31.12.2030.

 

Underlying SAP BW release 

Maintenance SAP BW release until 

Corresponding SAP BPC release  

Maintenance SAP BPC until 

SAP BW 7.50 *

31.12.2027‚ÄØ PAM 

SAP BPC 10.1 *

31.12.2027‚ÄØPAM 

SAP BW4/HANA 2.0 

31.12.2025‚ÄØ PAM 

SAP BPC 11.1 

31.12.2025‚ÄØPAM 

SAP BW4/HANA 2021 

31.12.2027‚ÄØ PAM 

SAP BPC 2021 

31.12.2030‚ÄØPAM 

SAP BW4/HANA 2023 

31.12.2030‚ÄØ PAM 

SAP BPC 2021 

31.12.2030‚ÄØPAM 

* Both SAP BW 7.50 and SAP BPC 10.1 have optional extended maintenance until 31.12.2030

 

SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 10.1, optimized for S/4HANA

SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 10.1 for S/4HANA lifecycle is aligned with S/4HANA itself, hence end of maintenance timeline is also aligned with each version of S/4HANA On Premise or S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition. Please visit PAM page of corresponding S/4HANA product version. 

Accordingly,  this BPC product follows S/4HANA maintenance extension until at least 2040.

 

SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 10.1, version for SAP Microsoft

SAP Business Planning and Consolidation 10.1 MS has mainstream maintenance until 30.06.2026(PAM). After the stated deadline, there will be no further prolongations and maintenance will be customer specific, according to SAP Note 52505. For more information on SAP's release and maintenance strategy, visit the dedicated pages on the SAP Support Portal.

Customers on this product platform are highly recommended to migrate solution to SAP Business Data Cloud.

 

The overall SAP Business Planning and Consolidation strategy is described in the following diagram.

entry.title: Sequential Processing of Allocation Cycles in Universal Allocation
entry.content:
This blog is part of our ongoing ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù series exploring Universal Allocation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. In this post, we‚Äôll dive into the principles of sequential processing of allocation cycles during an allocation run.

Sequential Processing in Regular Allocation Cycles

For the purpose of this article, we‚Äôll define the following allocation types as regular:

- Overhead Allocation
- Distribution
- Intercompany Allocation

When processing regular cycles within a single allocation run, an intermediary cache temporarily stores the results of each cycle. These results are then passed to subsequent cycles in the sequence.

Example

In this example, two cycles are processed sequentially within one allocation run, with an embedded dependency.

Cycle 1 (CC_SEQ1): Costs for building maintenance are allocated from the Building cost collector cost center to other cost centers (such as HR, IT, or Sales Management).

 




Cycle 2 (CC_SEQ2): Building maintenance and other costs are further reallocated from Sales Management to individual sales departments.

 

Using the Allocation Run app (or via Schedule Overhead Accounting Jobs), we select both cycles in the correct sequence and add them to the run worklist.

 

The application processes both cycles as part of a single allocation run.

 

In the Receivers tab of the result report, you can see that the receiver object from Cycle 1 becomes the sender in Cycle 2, confirming proper sequential processing.

 

Thanks to temporary data persistence between cycles, both CC_SEQ1 and CC_SEQ2 are processed within the same allocation run job. Initial costs are correctly reallocated through both steps in sequence to the final receivers.

Sequential Processing in Top-Down Distribution

With the introduction of Universal Allocation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the architecture of top-down distribution cycles has changed significantly. Compared to regular cycles, top-down distribution involves greater complexity and larger data volumes, which makes intermediary persistence within a single allocation run job not feasible.

Why it Matters

Sequential processing is highly valued by customers aiming to accelerate their period-end closing procedures. Without it, users have to wait for each individual cycle to finish before manually starting the next one.

Since intermediary caching is not possible due to data volume constraints, we introduced an alternative solution for top-down distribution.

How It Works

When running multiple top-down distribution cycles in a live run, a new control appears in the run dialog. This allows users to choose whether to process cycles sequentially, meaning that each cycle depends on the results of the previous one.

If sequential processing is selected, the system automatically splits the job into individual runs that are processed in sequence. The first cycle is processed, and once its results are posted to the Universal Journal (ACDOCA), the next cycle is triggered automatically‚Äîno manual intervention required.

Example

Let‚Äôs consider two top-down distribution cycles we want to process in a single run job with sequential processing:
- TDD_SEQ1: Distributes from Sales Organization to Customer Group level.
- TDD_SEQ2: Further distributes from Customer Group to individual Customer Detail level.

The user prepares a run worklist containing both cycles. Upon selecting the Live Run option, the system detects multiple top-down distribution cycles and presents the Sequential Processing option in the dialog.

 

When the user selects the Live Run option, the system detects multiple top-down distribution cycles and presents the Sequential Processing option in the dialog.

 

 

Users can choose between two modes:
- Run sequentially but Stop on Error:  If any cycle ends with an error, processing stops. For example, if five cycles are in the worklist and Cycle 3 fails, then the processing of Cycles 4 and 5 is canceled. If the Situation Framework is enabled, the user is notified and can decide how to proceed.
- Run sequentially but Stop on Warning: If any cycle ends with a warning, processing stops. The user must decide how to continue.

 

In our example, the user selects Stop on Error. After initiating the run:
1. The first cycle is processed, and the first run appears in the Allocation Results app.
2. The second run job is automatically triggered after the first finishes, and the second cycle is processed.

The run report in Allocation Results shows that the initial run was split into two jobs, with data from TDD_SEQ1 used as input for TDD_SEQ2.

 

 

Summary

Sequential processing enables the handling of cycles with data dependencies. It is supported for both regular allocation cycles and top-down distribution cycles, though each uses a different method:
- Regular cycles use intermediary caching within a single run.
- Top-down distribution uses automatic job splitting and Universal Journal persistence.
This flexibility helps streamline allocation processes and supports faster, more efficient period-end closing.

entry.title: Re: Forecasting in Intercompany Stock Transfer Scenario
entry.content:
Hello @Sindhu_Ravi 

I don't think you have any disconnect in your process and your scenario is a very common standard process:

  1. Demand (forecast) is planned in plant B (selling plant) with planned independent requirements (PIRs).
  2. Plant A supplies plant B. Therefore when MRP is executed in plant B, it will create purchase requisitions for stock transfer from plant A to B.
  3. The requisitions are converted to stock transfer orders and the orders are executed. Thus, stock is transferred from plant A to B. The stock in plant B covers the demand. Notice that you don't have PIRs in plant B, therefore there is no demand to be consumed there.
  4. Sales process is executed in plant B. That consumes PIRs (demand/forecast) in plant B. End of the story.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: Parameter Take values from source file/staging table...
entry.content:
Hello @0uTY 

Thanks for flagging the Migration Cockpit message.

Parameter Take values from source file/staging table' has not been fully maintained.

This message appears when a migration object contains control parameter tasks that are not fully maintained, often at the item or sub-item level. The cockpit will not proceed until all related structures have this parameter set and are confirmed.

What should you do?

Open your migration project ‚Üí Mapping Tasks ‚Üí Control Parameter Tasks for the affected object.

For each structure level (header, item, or sub-items), select one option and confirm:

0001 ‚Äì Take values from source file/staging table, or 0002 ‚Äì Take default values ‚Ä¶ (wording varies by object). SAP Help Portal-Control Parameter Tasks

Return to the project and run Prepare / Simulate again. SAP Help Portal-Migrate Data Using Staging Tables

KBA explicitly shows options 0001/0002. Missing maintenance on lower levels often causes issues for multi-level objects. KBA 3601494 - Migration Cockpit: Part of the Data is not being migrated because of inconsistencies in Staging Tables

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Creation of a simple Turnover Analysis with Stories in People Analytics
entry.content:
Hi @FrankErle 

I created a Turnover Analysis report via a Story Report for one of our clients. One of the key calculated fields in the report is defined as:
Turnover Rate (%) = (Last 12 Months Termination Count / Average of Last 12 Months Headcount) 
The definitions used are:
Last 12 Months Termination Count = Sum of terminations from the current month through the past 11 months
Average of Last 12 Months Headcount = (Sum of headcount for current month through the past 11 months) / 12

However, when presenting the data in a table with business units or legal entities as rows, the turnover is currently being calculated at the individual user level and then summed up for each business unit or legal entity. This results in an inflated turnover rate. Ideally, the turnover should be calculated at the aggregated level per business unit or legal entity using the total terminations and average headcount for that specific group.

Could you guide me on what steps I need to take in my report to ensure the calculation is done at the Business Unit or Legal Entity level?

entry.title: How to Dynamically Switch OData Services in SAP List Report Based on Filter Selection
entry.content:
I'm working with SAP Fiori Elements List Report application using the standard template (SAP UI5 version 1.96+). I have the following setup:

  • Service 1: /sap/opu/odata/sap/ZUI_SD_04_V2/ exposing entity set zc_header_04
  • Service 2: /sap/opu/odata/sap/ZUI_SD_LOG_04_V2/ exposing entity set zi_sd_04
  • Both services are configured in manifest.json as separate models

Requirement:

I have a custom filter bar (ComboBox) with two options:

  • Main - should display data from Service 1 (zc_header_04)
  • Log - should display data from Service 2 (zi_sd_04)

When the user changes the ComboBox selection, I want the List Report table to dynamically switch to the corresponding OData service and reload the data.

Current Implementation:

manifest.json:

 
 
json
"models": {
  "": {
    "dataSource": "mainService",
    "preload": true
  },
  "logModel": {
    "dataSource": "logService",
    "preload": true
  }
}

Extension Controller (ListReportExt.controller.jsüòû

 
 
javascript
onDataSourceChange: function (oEvent) {
    const sSelectedKey = oEvent.getSource().getSelectedKey();
    const oSmartTable = this.byId("listReport");
    
    if (sSelectedKey === "log") {
        oSmartTable.setModel(this.getView().getModel("logModel"));
        oSmartTable.setEntitySet("zi_sd_04");
    } else {
        oSmartTable.setModel(this.getView().getModel());
        oSmartTable.setEntitySet("zc_header_04");
    }
    
    oSmartTable.rebindTable();
}

Custom Filter Fragment:

 
 
xml
<smartfilterbar:ControlConfiguration key="CustomFilter">
    <smartfilterbar:customControl>
        <ComboBox id="dataSourceComboBox" selectedKey="main">
            <core:Item key="main" text="Main"/>
            <core:Item key="log" text="Log"/>
        </ComboBox>
    </smartfilterbar:customControl>
</smartfilterbar:ControlConfiguration>

Issues:

  1. When switching services, I get errors related to entity set not found
  2. The ComboBox selectionChange event is not triggering properly in the SmartFilterBar context
  3. Table doesn't rebind correctly after model switch

entry.title: Re: MMPV _closing the period - runtime error as 'DBSQL_DU...
entry.content:
The error typically occurs when the system attempts to insert a record into a database table that already contains a record with the same key. In the context of MMPV (period close), this may involve tables like CKMLPP, CKMLCR, or MLHD, which store material ledger and period data. SAP Note 3202191 addresses a known issue but may not cover all scenarios, especially if the database already contains inconsistent or duplicate entries.

To fix this issue,

analyze the Short Dump via ST22, Identify the exact table and key causing the duplicate error. Look for lines like INSERT <TABLE_NAME> or DBIF_DSQL2_ARRAY_INSERT.  If you are not familiar with ST22, take the help of ABAP team and find out the root cause.

go to SE14, check the affected table for duplicate entries. If safe and confirmed, you may need to manually delete or adjust the duplicate record (only in a test or sandbox system first).

Use transactions like CKMSTART, CKM3, or CKM3N to verify material ledger consistency. Run CKMC to check for open periods and inconsistencies.

entry.title: Re: Pasting multiple components in maintenance order comp...
entry.content:
Hi Daniel Cauba

Currently, SAP does not provide a standard feature that allows you to directly paste multiple components from Excel into the Components tab of a Maintenance Order (IW31 / IW32). The standard functionality only supports copying components from an existing order or template, but bulk pasting from the clipboard is not available. However, it is possible to use a script-based approach as a workaround.

The standard and recommended method is to prepare a Bill of Material (BOM) for the equipment or functional location (using transaction IB01). Then, in the Components tab of the order(IW31-IW32), by clicking the List button, all items from the BOM will be displayed, and you can select all of them directly from the menu.

I hope this answer helps improve your work process and provides some clarity for your approach

entry.title: Re: Invalid character/Bad Character removal in BW4HANA using AMDP Class
entry.content:
Hi Lakshminarasimhan

 

The usage of [:print:] might cause a problem if the loaded data contains non-latin characters  like:

  • japanese
  • chinese
  • cyrillic
  • etc

So this:

SELECT
replace_regexpr( '([^[:print:]]|[#|!])' in "T1" with ' ' occurrence all ) as T1,
replace_regexpr( '([^[:print:]]|[#|!])' in "T2" with ' ' occurrence all ) as T2,
replace_regexpr( '([^[:print:]]|[#|!])' in "T3" with ' ' occurrence all ) as T3,
replace_regexpr( '([^[:print:]]|[#|!])' in "T4" with ' ' occurrence all ) as T4
FROM ( SELECT
'Á•ù‰Ω†‰ªäÂ§©ÊÑâÂø´ Aabc123' as T1,
'–ü—Ä–∏—î–º–Ω–æ–≥–æ –¥–Ω—è! Aabc123' as T2,
'ËâØ„ÅÑ‰∏ÄÊó•„Çí Aabc123' as T3,
'Have a nice day Aabc123' as T4
FROM dummy)

has the effect, that every which are non-latin characters will be also removed.

 

See the KBA:

3386808 Unexpected result when replace_regexpr and :PRINT: is used in a HANA transformation

 

Br,

Roland

entry.title: SAC Rapid Finance (S/4HC Public, 2FM / guide 2JV) ‚Äî Actuals OK, but Copy‚ÜíPlan writes 0 and Ca
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We‚Äôre deploying SAP Analytics Cloud Rapid Finance on S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition. We followed configuration guide 2JV and have scope item 2FM active.

Environment

  • S/4: Public Edition (2FM active)

  • SAC content/model: SAP_FI_FPA_S4_Finance_Planning (FPA1 / H1)

  • Versions: public.Actual (OK), public.Plan (targets)

  • CoA: YCOA master; YBSE is an alternative CoA (no hierarchy in S/4)

  • Org master: No hierarchies for Cost Center/Profit Center/Functional Area (leafs only)

What works

  • Actuals import runs and we can report Actuals in SAC (P&L/BS).

Issues

  1. Copy Actuals ‚Üí Plan (delivered step) runs but writes 0 to Plan.

  2. Cash Flow (Indirect) doesn‚Äôt populate the 13 CF lines. We added the CF accounts in SAC.

  3. GLAccountBalanceFlow import finishes, but ~30% rows are rejected.

What we already did

  • Account dimension: Exported, then manually mapped ACCTYPEand Rate Type (Closing/Average) because S/4 account types (e.g., X, P‚Ä¶) didn‚Äôt map 1:1.

  • Added 13 CF holder accounts in SAC (all ACCTYPE=EXP, RateType=Average):
    1000100, 1000210, 1000310, 1000320, 1000330, 1000350, 1000360, 2000111, 2000210, 2000400, 3000100, 3000200, 3000300.
    Initially not in a hierarchy; we then adjusted our AFL to reference them directly to avoid compile errors‚Äîstill no CF values written.

  • Copy AFL (simplified) tried in addition to delivered step (uses target version‚Äôs Start/End date, includes # members or removes org dims, writes to AUDIT_TRAIL="SAC"):

CONFIG.HIERARCHY = [d/SAP_XPA_ACCOUNT].[h/H1]
MEMBERSET [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/StartDate] TO [d/Version].[p/EndDate]
MEMBERSET [d/AUDIT_TRAIL] = "SAC"
MEMBERSET [d/SAP_XPA_ACCOUNT] = BASEMEMBER([d/SAP_XPA_ACCOUNT].[h/H1], "FPA1/08","FPA1/00ASSETS","FPA1/00LIABILITS")
DATA() = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Version]="public.Actual")

  • GLAccountBalanceFlow query (for the Finance model import) - typical filters used:

    • Controlling Area = A000

    • Ledger = 0L

    • GLAcct Type Flow = PLCHANGING; ‚Ä¶

    • Fiscal Period = 1 ‚Üí 12

    • Fiscal Year of Ledger = 2025
      Job finishes, but the monitor shows a high ‚ÄúRejected‚Äù count.

Questions for the community

  1. Copy step writing 0: common causes in Rapid Finance? (e.g., version not in Edit, publish/locks, AuditTrail choice, required Measures, missing # in org dims, etc.)

  2. Cash-Flow (Indirect):

    • Must the 13 CF holder accounts be in H1 under specific parents, or is ‚Äúexisting as leafs‚Äù enough?

    • Are ACCTYPE=EXP and RateType=Average the expected properties for these CF lines?

  3. GLAccountBalanceFlow rejections (~30%): Where do you typically find the root cause? (dimension validation, account attributes, currency/rate-type, hierarchy assumptions‚Ä¶) Any checklist?

  4. Any official mapping guidance from S/4 account type codes (X, P, etc.) to SAC ACCTYPE and Rate Type used by Rapid Finance?

  5. With YCOA master and YBSE alternative (no S/4 hierarchies), are there extra steps needed so Rapid Finance acts like the content expects?

Evidence I can attach

  • Import run log (showing ‚ÄúRejected‚Äù rows)

  • GLAccountBalanceFlow filter screenshot

  • FPA1/H1 snippet + CF accounts list

  • Data Action run screenshots and AFL snippets

Any pointers or a working checklist would be hugely appreciated. Thanks!

Axel Mutombo

entry.title: Re: S/4 Cloud: Local Event Consumption not getting triggered
entry.content:
Hi @yoppy_santoso1,

I raised an incident for this. SAP then reactivated the corresponding RAP behavior definition, then it worked. Unfortunately you cannot do this yourself, since it is an SAP standard object (at least I don't know any way to do it without getting an authorization error in eclipse during activation). You might also try to just bring your implementation to your test system, maybe the issue is only on dev (even though this is not nice, but if you want to speed things up, it might be worth a try). If you raise an incident, you could tell SAP that they found a solution for this in incident nr. 815224/2025 (maybe that helps speeding things up as well). Of course I can't know if really have the same issue as we had.

Best regards
Daniel

entry.title: SAP Joule for Developers Expands to Private Cloud: Accelerating ABAP Innovation and Transformation
entry.content:
Key Highlights

  • Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now available in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition 2025.
  • New Custom Code Migration capabilities accelerate the transformation of classic ERP code to S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including:
    • Documentation Chat - Get accurate answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications.
    • ABAP Program Explain - Understand the business purpose and logic of legacy code.
    • Explain for SAP S/4HANA Test Cockpit Issues - Diagnose and resolve S/4HANA-related Test Cockpit issues using context from simplification items and cookbooks.

Earlier this year, SAP introduced Joule for Developers ‚Äî a set of embedded artificial intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, including ABAP, that helps developers accelerate application and extension development, reduce costs, and boost productivity.

Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now available for S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition, version 2025, providing comprehensive support for ABAP Cloud use cases. The release also introduces the first Custom Code Migration capabilities, bringing a powerful suite of AI-assisted capabilities purpose-built for ABAP development and cloud delivery.

Best of all, Joule for Developers remains free of charge, enabling customers and partners to integrate it into daily operations and accelerate innovation without commercial barriers.

 

What‚Äôs Included

This release for Private Cloud delivers AI-powered support for the core development scenarios ABAP developers rely on every day. Key capabilities include:

  • inline code completion,
  • ABAP/CDS code explanation,
  • automated unit test generation for ABAP and ABAP core data services (CDS),
  • RAP business objects generation,
  • RAP predictive business logic, and
  • OData consumption.

All capabilities are designed to accelerate development, improve code quality, and boost productivity from day one. Additionally, this release introduces the first wave of Custom Code Migration capabilities, designed to accelerate the move from classic SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Cloud Edition. These AI-powered features simplify code analysis and adaptation by:

  • Providing Documentation Chat for quick answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications:

 

  • Using ABAP Program Explain to clarify the business purpose and implementation logic of legacy code:

 

  • Explaining ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) findings with step-by-step guidance on how to fix the issues, based on simplification items and technical documentation:

 

All capabilities are designed to reduce manual effort, speed up migration projects, and help your teams to modernize their ABAP landscapes with great confidence.

The ABAP AI software development kit, powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management, is now available and offers centralized access to the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core. It leverages the same robust platform SAP uses internally, delivering proven, production-grade infrastructure to customer landscapes. With simplified configuration and governance, development teams can adopt AI capabilities quickly, providing a significant boost to integration efforts.

 

Why This Matters

Private cloud customers require strict governance, security, and operational control - yet they also seek the speed and innovation modern AI-driven development delivers. This release addresses both priorities by enabling:

  • faster development cycles with AI-assisted coding and test generation,
  • stronger knowledge transfer through automated code explanations and copilot interactions,
  • higher delivery quality with automated testing and code migration support, and
  • secure innovation within controlled environments.

 

Looking Ahead

We‚Äôre building on this momentum with a series of targeted deliveries aligned to upcoming releases across the BTP ABAP Environment and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Planned updates for BTP ABAP Environment 2511, 2602, and S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 include:

  • documentation generation capabilities,
  • enhanced explanations for reports in the Custom Code Migration application,
  • AI-enabled insights on Clean Core‚Äìrelated ATC findings directly within the Custom Code Migration application,
  • code migration and adaptation proposals to support developers working on RISE code adaptation,
  • ABAP CDS annotation and metadata extension generation, and
  • ABAP CDS analytical model generation.

These enhancements will extend Joule‚Äôs impact beyond code completion and test generation, supporting documentation, migration and Clean Core compliance, analytical use cases, and addressing more stages of the end-to-end development lifecycle.

 

Free Offer Extended

SAP Joule for Developers will remain free of charge. The extended promotion ensures that all customers and partners can continue to use Joule for Developers capabilities for free.

Access can be requested using the material numbers 8019124 (customers) and 8019541 (TDD partners). This offer now extends beyond the BTP ABAP environment and SAP Cloud ERP Public Edition to include SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition customers running the latest 2025 release.

 

Closing Remarks

SAP Joule for Developers‚Äô delivery for Private Cloud is a significant milestone ‚Äî combining end-to-end ABAP Cloud with AI use cases, innovative code migration scenarios, and a standardized ABAP AI SDK to bring practical AI assistance directly into everyday development workflows.

With extended free of charge access, we invite every customer and partner to explore SAP Joule for Developers, push its boundaries, and help shape the future of AI-assisted ABAP development.

Start using SAP Joule for Developers today and join us in building the next generation of intelligent, AI-driven ABAP innovation.

For a deeper dive, read the blog post by Simona Marincei, head of ABAP AI.

Learn more about SAP Joule for Developers capabilities here.

entry.title: Re: SAP certificate renewal - practical guide
entry.content:
Hi @DurgaKalyan1 

the updated certificate should be provided by the holder of the private key, ie. the party with which you communicate. The public certificate is used to encrypt the message or to verify signature. The private key is used to decrypt the message or to sign. So if your communication partner is decrypting your messages, it should provide you with the certificate.

Nevertheless, this is a reverse scenario to one I was describing in the blog. The blog is about when you are the owner of the private part of the certificate, like in the case of the SAP certificate.

In your case, your partner should inform you about the certificate exchange in time and provide you with the new certificate. You can send them this blog üôÇ

entry.title: Automating Job Requisition Creation Without Middleware
entry.content:
In this article, I‚Äôll walk you through how to automate job requisition creation in SAP SuccessFactors‚Äîwithout relying on any middleware solutions. By leveraging Intelligence Services Center (ISC) and Integration Center, we can streamline the process and reduce dependency on external systems.

Key Events Used in ISC:

  1. Update a Position
  2. New Position

These events allow us to trigger requisition creation automatically. Depending on the business need, you can configure the system to generate either:

  • Approved Requisitions: Set IsDraft = false and ensure all mandatory fields are populated.
  • Pre-Approved Requisitions: Set IsDraft = true and map relevant position attributes.

Process Overview:

Process 1:
When a new position is created in the system, the Intelligent Services Center (ISC) event is automatically triggered. This event initiates the integration flow, which seamlessly creates the corresponding job requisition‚Äîno middleware is required for this process.

To implement this automation, we need to create an integration specifically for the ISC event: New Position.

Steps to Create the Integration:

  1. Navigate to Integration Center in your SAP SuccessFactors instance.
  2. Click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù to start a new integration.
  3. Select ‚ÄúMore Integration Types‚Äù to access additional integration templates.
  4. Choose the appropriate template or start from scratch, depending on your requirements.
  5. Configure the integration to listen for the New Position ISC event and define the logic to create a job requisition accordingly.

Now, set the Trigger Type to Intelligent Services.
For both the Source Type and Destination Type, select SuccessFactors.
Ensure the Format is set to OData.

After clicking on create button, select the intelligent service as shown below.

 

Selecting the Appropriate ISC Event and Configuring the Integration

  • If the integration should automatically create a job requisition whenever a new position is created, select the ISC event: ‚ÄúNew Position‚Äù.
  • If the integration should trigger when an existing position is updated, select the ISC event: ‚ÄúUpdate to a Position‚Äù.

Once the appropriate Intelligent Services event is selected:

  1. The Source Type will automatically be set to Position.
  2. Next, define the Destination system (SuccessFactors).
  3. Proceed to map the required entities and fields between the source and destination to ensure accurate data flow.

Select the Destination type as Job requisition

Now, proceed to map the necessary fields from the Position object to the Job Requisition object.
This step ensures that all relevant data from the position is accurately transferred to the requisition during the integration process.

Mandatory Job Requisition Fields and Their Values

The following fields in the Job Requisition entity must be populated during integration to ensure successful creation:

S.No

Field

Value

Condition/Notes

1

Application Template ID

Template ID

Must match the ID defined in the Job Requisition template.

2

Internal Status

0 for Pre-Approved
1 for Approved

Determines the initial approval status of the requisition.

3

Application Status Set ID

Status Set ID

Should align with the status set configured in the Job Requisition template.

4

Template ID

Requisition Template ID

Must correspond to the correct Job Requisition template.

5

IsDraft

True ‚Äì for Pre-Approved
False ‚Äì for Approved

If set to False, ensure all mandatory fields are mapped and populated.

 

Map the required fields between the Position and Job Requisition entities as outlined below:

S.No

Field Type

Mapping

1

Object

Position_object.externalCode ‚Üí JobReq_object.externalCode

2

Picklist

Position_picklist.optionID ‚Üí JobReq_picklist.ID (type: int64)

3

String

Position_field ‚Üí JobReq_field

After completing the field mapping between the Position and Job Requisition entities, apply a filter based on the "To Be Hired" flag.

  • This filter ensures that the integration only triggers for positions marked as eligible for hiring.
  • By adding this condition, the system will create job requisitions only for positions where the "To Be Hired" flag is enabled.

Once the filter is configured:

  1. Validate the integration setup to ensure all mappings and conditions are correctly defined.
  2. Click Save to finalize and activate the integration.

 

Solution :

To trigger the integration and automatically create a job requisition:

  • Create a new position either through the Position Org Chart or by importing data.
  • Once the position is created and meets the defined criteria (e.g., To Be Hired flag is enabled), the integration will automatically generate the corresponding Job Requisition.


Role Assignment and Route Map Configuration in Job Requisition

In the Job Requisition, roles can be dynamically assigned using Save Rules. Based on these rules, the Route Map is automatically updated to reflect the appropriate users involved in the approval and hiring process.

Extending the Same Logic to ISC Event: "Update to a Position"

Similarly, you can configure the Intelligent Services event: ‚ÄúUpdate to a Position‚Äù to trigger the integration.

  • Whenever this event is raised (e.g., due to a change in position details), the integration will execute and automatically create or update the Job Requisition based on the updated position data.
  • This ensures that any significant changes to an existing position‚Äîsuch as a change in department, location, or hiring need‚Äîcan seamlessly initiate the requisition process without manual intervention.

 

Automating Job Requisition Creation Using Intelligent Services and Integration Center

By leveraging the Intelligent Services Center (ISC) and Integration Center, you can automate the creation of Job Requisitions based on updates to Position details and predefined default values.

Additionally, if your organization uses multiple Job Requisition templates, you can utilize lookup tables within Integration Center to dynamically select the appropriate template. This can be achieved by configuring conditional logic based on specific Position field values.

 For example:

  • If Position.Department,Input code = "Sales", use Template Output code -XXX
  • If Position.Department.Input code = "Service", use Template Output code -YYY

This approach ensures that the correct requisition template is applied automatically, improving accuracy and reducing manual effort.



SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting
